docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 4 -- In the best tradition of the sea and of showmanship the United States Navy Band completed tonight its tour of South America, which had been marred by tragedy.
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 4 -- In the best tradition of the sea and of showmanship the United States Navy Band completed tonight its tour of South America, which had been marred by tragedy.
docs.abstract: tour ends with concert, Montevideo; hailed by Amb Howe; leader Comdr Brendler comments

docs.snippet: MAJOR ISSUES THE FILIBUSTER The South's arguments will be fully offered. The Northern press will give them short shrift. Even hereabouts, we shall pay relatively little attention to them, we know them so well.

byline.original: By FELIX BELAIR Jr.Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: BUENOS AIRES, March 5 -- As President Eisenhower roared off Buenos Aires airport in his Air Force jet transport Thursday morning, he left behind him in South America the warm glow of reawakened friendship for the United States and much hope that a...
docs.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES, March 5 -- As President Eisenhower roared off Buenos Aires airport in his Air Force jet transport Thursday morning, he left behind him in South America the warm glow of reawakened friendship for the United States and much hope that a new era finally has dawned in hemisphere relations.
docs.abstract: success of tour in cementing friendship for US discussed; speculation on US ability to fulfill promises and satisfy aroused expectations; cartoons

byline.original: By TAD SZULCSpecial to The New York Times

docs.snippet: President Eisenhower has logged some 45,000 miles and visited seventeen countries in three trips abroad since last August. Tomorrow he returns to Washington at the end of the third trip -- a nine-day tour of Latin America on which he covered 15,600...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Eisenhower has logged some 45,000 miles and visited seventeen countries in three trips abroad since last August. Tomorrow he returns to Washington at the end of the third trip -- a nine-day tour of Latin America on which he covered 15,600 miles, visited four countries, delivered six major and a score of minor speeches and was seen by upward of 3,000,000 persons.
